awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Ecological and evolutionary impacts of disrupted transmission on host-microbiome associations
awd_abstract_narration:
The microbiome living in or on an organism is critical to that organism's health. It influences everything from growth and development to behavior to disease susceptibility. How an organism gets the best possible microbiome during its development is key to its lifetime health and reproductive success. However, we know very little about how the processes by which microbiomes are transmitted among individuals affects organism health. This knowledge gap becomes especially important when building predictions about how interfering in the transfer of microbes between individuals might matter. For example, there has been discussion of how caesarean section birth might reduce the transmission of microbiota from mother to offspring, and in agriculture there are numerous common practices, such as sterilization of seeds or crop rotation, that likely impact the movement of plant-associated microbes across generations. This research project will focus on the consequences of differences in how tomatoes, a model agricultural crop, get their microbiomes. It will compare how vertical transmission, from parent to offspring, or horizontal transmission, among unrelated organisms, affects microbiome establishment, adaptation, and function. The outcomes of this work will be relevant to the development of agricultural practices that better incorporate the potentially useful role of the plant microbiome for crop yield. Undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will also be involved in the project, and researchers will also work with local teachers to create teaching materials based on the research. 

The proposed work uses a model tomato plant - phyllosphere (leaf associated) microbiome system to determine both the short term (ecological) and longer-term (evolutionary) consequences of interrupted microbiome transmission between generations on host-microbiome interactions. By manipulating the likelihood that seedlings will be colonized by microbiota coming from parental plants versus unrelated plants, the work will directly test the impact of transmission mode on microbiome successional dynamics, adaptation, and function. The combination of microbial experimental evolution, culture-independent sequencing, and metagenomic analyses will allow for a causal link to be established between microbiome transmission mode and the taxonomic and functional diversity of phyllosphere microbiota. The empirical work will be complemented by theory on how vertical microbiome transmission affects host-microbiome coevolution. Together, the work will determine the importance of vertical transmission in shaping host-microbiome interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The abundant and diverse microbial communities living in and on plants impact host phenotype and critically shape the evolution and ecology of host populations. These microbiomes influence everything from pathogen susceptibility to range expansion and an organism?s ability to cope with stressful environments, and yet we still know relatively little about how these communities assemble. This project aimed to determine how microbiome transmission (i.e. vertical transmission from seeds versus horizontal transmission from neighboring plants) impacts adaptation of these communities to their hosts. We combined field studies, controlled microbiome passaging in the greenhouse, experimental evolution in the lab, culture-independent microbial community profiling, and mathematical modeling to address this question in both system-specific and system-agnostic ways. In a series of 5 resulting publications from this project (with 2 additional preprints and 1 further paper in preparation), we have shown how important the source of microbial inoculum (i.e. dispersal) and the arrival order of microbial taxa (i.e. priority effects) are to microbiome community assembly, how microbiomes can adapt to their host environment across multiple generations, and how both of these processes impact and are impacted by the likelihood that microbial taxa are transmitted among conspecifics (e.g. individuals of the same species) versus heterospecific hosts. For example, by manipulating the local plant neighborhood in which a focal plant lived, we showed how plant ?filtering? (their ability to recruit a specific microbiome) depended critically on who they were surrounded by. Similarly, using a series of microbiome ?passaging? experiments (where microbiomes were experimentally transmitted from one generation to the next over time), we found that microbiomes become more specialized to their hosts over time and, in doing so, become less invadable by new bacterial taxa. Our empirical work complemented these findings through conceptual development of how transmission mode shapes all aspects of host-microbiome interactions, including the critical window during which microbiomes are tolerated by the host immune system, as well as how microbiomes shape host evolution over time. Ultimately, this basic science research rooted in fundamental principles of ecology and evolution allowed us to reshape and rethink how we approach agricultural problems, especially in light of our changing planet. Through our publications, outreach, and teaching, this funding supported translation of understanding of how plant microbiomes assemble in naturally diverse plant communities in the absence of seed treatments and chemical application to guide new agricultural practices and conservation approaches that fully leverage the power of the plant microbiome for plant health.
